column1: A Coruña (Galician: [ɐ koˈɾuɲɐ]; Spanish: La Coruña [la koˈɾuɲa]; historical English: Corunna or The Groyne) is a city and municipality of Galicia
column2: Spain. It is the second most populated city and the second most populated municipality in the autonomous community and seventeenth overall in the country. The city is the provincial capital of the province of the same name
column3: having also served as political capital of the Kingdom of Galicia from the 16th to the 19th centuries
column4: and as a regional administrative centre between 1833 and 1982
column5: before being replaced by Santiago de Compostela.

column1: A Coruña is a busy port located on a promontory in the Golfo Ártabro
column2: a large gulf on the Atlantic Ocean. Being exposed to Atlantic winds and low-pressure systems bringing plenty of rainfall for most of the year
column3: it has the coolest summers of Spain's major urban areas
column4: but likewise has very mild winters for its latitude. It is the main industrial and financial centre of northern Galicia
column5: and holds the headquarters of the Universidade da Coruña.

column1: There is no clear evidence as to what the name derives from. It seems to be from Crunia
column2: of unknown origin and meaning. At the time of Ferdinand II of León (reigned 1157–1188) the name Crunia was documented for the first time. As usual in Galician-Portuguese (as well as in Castilian Spanish)
column3: the cluster ni naturally evolved into the sound [ɲ]
column4: written n
column5: nn or nh in old Galician orthography
column6: nn in Spanish (later abbreviated to ñ
column7: like the original Latin cluster "nn")
column8: and nh in Portuguese and alternative Galician spelling. "A" is the Galician article equivalent to English the; compare Castilian Spanish la ("the").

column1: One proposed etymology derives Crunia from Cluny
column2: the town in France. During its height (c. 950–c.1130) the Cluniac religious movement became very prominent in Europe. There is another town named Coruña in Burgos Province.

column1: Another possibility is that the name means simply "The Crown". The Galician word for "crown" is coroa. It is also possible it came about through changes to the French La Couronne
column2: also meaning "the Crown". It seems less likely that it traces back to the Galician clunia. The name is reputedly from the Greek Κορώνα (Crown)
column3: referring to the crown of Geryon that was buried by Hercules under the lighthouse he built to his honour. The hero Hercules slew the giant tyrant Geryon after three days and three nights of continuous battle. Hercules then—in a Celtic gesture—buried the head of Geryon with his weapons and ordered that a city be built on the site. The lighthouse atop a skull and crossbones representing the buried head of Hercules' slain enemy appears in the coat-of-arms of the city of Coruña
column4: Loukeris (2019).A proxy evolution within the Portuguese language points out the Latin word Colonya as its origin
column5: where the L was transformed in R which occurs widely in Portuguese
column6: for example in Brazilian rural areas outwards the cities and towns environment. A similar happening can be found in Coronie today's a Surinamese town which also made it course outside the Portuguese system.

column1: A folk etymology incorrectly derives Coruña from the ancient columna
column2: or Tower of Hercules.
use of the Spanish or Galician forms now predominates. However
column3: the traditional English form Corunna  can persist
column4: particularly in reference to the Battle of Corunna (1809) in the Peninsular War. Archaically
column5: English-speakers knew the city as "The Groyne"
column6: probably from French La Corogne.

column2: the only official form of the name is now the Galician one: "A Coruña".

column1: Certain groups of people have advocated elevating the reintegrationist spelling "Corunha" to official status
column2: pointing to the provisions of the Spanish Constitution of 1978 and claiming that it is unconstitutional to stipulate use of the Real Academia Galega spelling
column3: but they have not been successful as of 2018.

column1: A Coruña is located on a peninsula
column2: and its isthmus was at times formed only by a small strip of sand. Erosion and sea currents caused a progressive accumulation of sand
column3: enlarging it to its present dimensions.

column1: A Coruña has an oceanic climate (Cfb)
column2: bordering on a warm-summer Mediterranean climate (Csb)
column3: in the Köppen climate classification. Autumn and winter are often unsettled and unpredictable
column4: with strong winds and abundant rainfall coming from Atlantic depressions
column5: and it is often overcast. The ocean keeps temperatures mild
column6: and frost and snow are rare.

column2: with occasional rainfall
column3: usually in the form of drizzle; high temperatures are warm but rarely uncomfortably hot because of the sea's cooling influence during the day
column4: most often being around 22 °C (72 °F) between July and September.

column1: Spring is usually cool and fairly calm. Even the warmest month on record was relatively subdued
column2: being August 2003
column3: with an average high temperature of 25 °C (77 °F). Temperatures above 25 °C (77 °F) occur many days in the summer
column4: while temperatures above 30 °C (86 °F) are infrequent.

column1: A Coruña spread from the peninsula where the Tower of Hercules stands
column2: onto the mainland. The oldest part
column3: known popularly in Galician as Cidade Vella (Old City)
column4: Cidade Alta (High City) or the Cidade (City)
column5: is built on an ancient Celtic castro. It was supposedly inhabited by the Brigantes and Artabrians
column6: the Celtic tribes of the area.

column1: The Romans came to the region in the 2nd century BC; they made the most of the strategic position and soon the city became quite important in maritime trade. In 62 BC Julius Caesar came to the city (known at the time as Brigantium) in pursuit of the metal trade
column2: establishing commerce with what are now France
column3: England and Portugal. The town began to grow
column4: mainly during the 1st and 2nd centuries (when the Farum Brigantium Tower of Hercules was built)
column5: but declined after the 4th century and particularly with the incursions of the Normans
column6: which forced the population to flee towards the interior of the Estuary of O Burgo.

column1: After the fall of the Roman Empire
column2: A Coruña still had a commercial port connected to foreign countries
column3: but contacts with the Mediterranean were slowly replaced by a more Atlantic-oriented focus.

column1: The process of deurbanisation that followed the fall of the Roman Empire also affected A Coruña. Between the 7th and 8th centuries
column2: the city was no more than a little village of labourers and sailors.

column1: The 11th-century Chronica iriense names Faro do Burgo (ancient name of A Coruña) as one of the dioceses that king Miro granted to the episcopate of Iria Flavia in the year 572:

Mirus Rex Sedi suae Hiriensi contulit Dioceses, scilicet Morratium, Salinensem, (...) Bregantinos, Farum..."[King Miro granted to his Irienses headquarters the dioceses of Morrazo, Salnés (...). Bergantiños, Faro...]The Muslim invasion of the Iberian peninsula left no archaeological evidence in the northwest
column2: so it cannot be said whether or not the Muslim invaders ever reached the city. As Muslim rule in early 8th century Galicia consisted little more than a short-lived overlordship of the remote and rugged region backed by a few garrisons
column3: and the city was no more than a village amidst Roman ruins
column4: the invaders showed the same lack of interest in the ruined city as they did generally for the region.

column1: As the city began to recover during the Middle Ages the main problem for the inhabitants was the Norman raids
column2: as well as the ever-present threat of raids (razzias) from Al-Andalus to the south. During the 9th century there were several Viking attacks on the city
column3: called at that time Faro or Faro Bregancio.

column2: King Vermudo II began the construction of defensive military positions on the coast. At Faro
column3: in the ruins of the Tower of Hercules
column4: a fortress was built
column5: which had a permanent military garrison. To pay for it
column6: he gave power over the city to the bishop of Santiago. The bishop of Santiago became the most important political post in Galicia
column7: and remained so until the 15th century.

column2: Alfonso IX re-founded the city of Crunia. Some privileges
column3: such as those of disembarking and selling salt without paying taxes
column4: were granted to the city
column5: and it enjoyed a big growth in fishing and mercantile business. The city grew and extended through the isthmus. In 1446 John II of Castile granted to A Coruña the title of "City". The Catholic Monarchs established the Royal Audience of the Kingdom of Galicia in the city
column6: instead of Santiago. A Coruña also became the headquarters of the Captaincy General. Later
column8: Charles V conceded to the city of A Coruña the license to establish the House of Spices
column9: being this the port chosen by Jofre Garcia de Loysa to set his expedition to conquer the Moluccans.

column2: before the expulsion of the Jews in 1492
column3: a thriving Jewish community created a rich artistic heritage in the city. The most lavishly illuminated Hebrew Bible in medieval Spain was created in A Coruña in 1476. Known as the Kennicott Bible
column4: it is currently housed in the Bodleian Library
column5: Oxford.

column2: the city was a port and centre for the manufacturing of textiles. In 1520
column3: king Carlos I of Spain
column4: met in the courts of A Coruña and embarked from its harbour to be elected Emperor of the Holy Roman Empire (as Charles V). He allowed the government of the Kingdom of Galicia to distribute spice in Europe between 1522 and 1529. Commerce with the Indies was allowed between 1529 and 1575. San Antón Castle was built as a defense of the city and its harbour.

column1: A Coruña was the site of the Battle of Corunna during the Peninsular War
column2: on 16 January 1809
column3: in which British troops fought against the French to cover the embarkation of British troops after their retreat. In this battle Sir John Moore was killed.

column1: Spanish resistance during the Peninsular War was led by Sinforiano López
column2: and A Coruña was the only Galician city that achieved success against the French troops.  French troops left Galicia at the end of May 1809.
the city was the centre of anti-monarchist sentiment.
Juan Díaz Porlier
column3: pronounced against Fernando VII in defense of the Spanish Constitution of 1812. He was supported by the bourgeoisie and the educated people. But on 22 August he was betrayed. He was hanged in the Campo da Leña two months later.

column1: The city is the site of the Roman Tower of Hercules
column2: a lighthouse which has been in continuous operation since possibly the 2nd century AD. It has been declared by UNESCO as a World Heritage Site. It is surrounded by a large public park with a golf course and the so-called Moor's Graveyard (Cemiterio do Moro in Galician
column3: Cementerio del Moro in Spanish) a building where in fact there were never burials
column4: Muslim or not
column5: which now houses the Casa das Palabras (Galician for House of Words) museum. The lighthouse features as the main emblem of the city's flag and coat of arms.The city is also well known for its characteristic glazed window balconies
column6: called galerías. Originally
column7: this type of structure came about as a naval architecture solution for the challenging weather
column8: particularly designed for rainy days. This fashion started in nearby Ferrol in the 18th century when some of the technicians working for the Royal Dockyards had the idea of using the shape of the back of a warship in a modern building. Soon afterward
column10: were adding these glazed window balconies to their city-port houses.

column3: it has spent all but three seasons in the top two tiers. Women's section of the team plays in Spain's top division.

column1: Deportivo won the league title once
column2: in the 1999–2000 season
column3: and finished as runners-up on five occasions. The club has also won the Spanish Cup twice (1995 and 2002)
column4: and three Spanish Super Cups. Between 2000–01 and 2004–05
column5: Deportivo played in the UEFA Champions League for five seasons in a row
column6: and reached the semi-finals in 2004.

column1: The city has a roller hockey team

column3: one of the most successful in Spain
column4: and the team plays in the main League OK Liga. They became Europe's Champions in 2011.

column1: Two Gaelic football teams were founded in 2010 and 2011
column2: A Coruña Fillos de Breogán (with men and ladies teams) and Ártabros de Oleiros (really originating in A Coruña too). They participate in the Iberian Championship and in the Galician League.
in the outskirts of the city

column2: A Coruña is home to the annual Teresa Herrera de Bowling tournament
column3: this year (2016) played from 24 to 28 August in the Pleno Bowling Centre
column4: Marineda City. It attracts players from all over Spain.

column1: Domingos Rafael Merino Mexuto was the first mayor after the Spanish Constitution of 1978 for the PSG party (he is now in the BNG party)
column2: and he currently works at the Galician Ombudsman's (Valedor) office.

column1: Francisco Vázquez Vázquez from the PSOE became mayor of the city in 1983; however
column2: on becoming the Spanish ambassador to the Vatican
column3: he was replaced by Javier Losada on 10 February 2006.

column1: The mayor of the 2015–2019 mandate was Xulio Ferreiro
column2: from the Marea Atlántica ("Atlantic Tide") party
column3: who was elected in 2015 on an anti-corruption mandate. His remit was to improve the town planning of the city rather than to leave it to the mercy of corrupt
column4: unregulated free-market policies which have left a negative legacy in many areas of the municipality. He has widespread support across the region in opposition to a project to sell off the city's port (a legacy of the preceding mayor Carlos Negreira) to a private equity firm
column5: which wants to construct a gated community of high-rise apartment blocks for which there is no real market demand in a city with a population of fewer than 250
column6: 000 inhabitants. The plan is to put a covenant on the land and to encourage a civic consultation on redevelopment of the site.
